'''Luther "Snake Boy" Johnson''' (August 30, 1934 – March 18, 1976) was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. He was also known as Luther "Snake" Johnson or Luther "Georgia Boy" Johnson, and was otherwise billed as both Luther King and Little Luther (under the latter he recorded for [[Chess Records]] in the 1960s).<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=[[Cub Koda]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/luther-snake-boy-johnson-mn0000805321/biography |title=Luther "Snake Boy" Johnson | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>

[[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Ron Wynn, stated "Johnson's own inimitable vocals, raspy lines and tart guitar eventually create his own aura...  a good, occasionally outstanding blues artist."<ref name="Torch">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=lonesome-in-my-bedroom-r115831|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Lonesome in My Bedroom'' > Overview|accessdate=March 21, 2012 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>

He is not to be confused with [[Luther Johnson (Guitar Junior)|Luther "Guitar Junior" Johnson]].

==Life and career==
He was born '''Lucious Brinson ''' in [[Davisboro, Georgia]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/> He was raised on a farm and taught himself to play guitar.<ref name="Keep">{{cite web |url=http://www.keeponliving.at/artist/luther_johnson.html |title=Luther Johnson |author=Anita Pravits |year=2012 |work= |publisher=Keeponliving.at|accessdate=March 21, 2012}}</ref>

After service in the [[United States Army|US Army]] up to 1953,<ref name="Keep"/> Johnson played guitar with a local [[gospel music|gospel]] [[musical ensemble|group]] called the Milwaukee Supreme Angels. However, he graduated towards [[blues]] and set up his own [[Trio (music)|trio]] in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], before relocating to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in the early 1960s.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Keep"/> He backed [[Elmore James]] prior to his death, and in 1964, released a solo [[Single (music)|single]] on the [[Chess Records]] label entitled "The Twirl", billed as Little Luther. He then joined [[Muddy Waters]] backing band in 1966. Johnson worked with various musicians over this period, including [[Chicago Bob Nelson]], before recording his debut album, ''Come on Home'' in 1969.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Keep"/>

In 1970, Johnson moved to [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], and found work on the blues [[music festival|festival]] and college circuits for the next few years.<ref name="AMG"/> [[Black & Blue Records]] released Johnson's ''Born in Georgia'' in 1972, and this was followed by ''Chicken Shack'' (1974), ''Lonesome in My Bedroom'' (1975), and the final album issued in his lifetime, ''Get Down to the Nitty Gritty'' (1976).<ref name="Keep"/><ref name="Albums"/>

Johnson died of [[cancer]] in Boston in March 1976, aged 41.<ref name="AMG"/> He was interred at the [[Mount Hope Cemetery (Boston, Massachusetts)|Mount Hope Cemetery]] in [[Mattapan]], Massachusetts.<ref name="Keep"/>
